container-title: In the days of the New Economic Policy (N.E.P
note: The revival of the private economy under the N.E.P. was brief. Some estimates of the interest rates charged and received have been reported, however, and are summarized in the table at the bottom of page 609.
title: nation developed its heavy industry, and after rationing had been abandoned in the 1930’s, these rates were brought down. They reached levels that were above the Western European prime rates of the 1930’s, but were below most earlier Russian rates. The great new inflation that followed World War II was apparently not allowed to bring back high official interest rates. The private economy that had been important in the 1920’s was almost entirely liquidated
the private economy had several sources of credit. It could occasionally borrow from government banks, it could form mutual credit societies, or it could borrow from municipal banks

note: they were permitted to charge 10–36% for small loans and 24–120% for
title: Pawnshops flourished in Soviet Russia during the 1920’s. Before World War I, pawnshop rates had been limited by law to 18–24%

note: Who would have predicted in 1989, when Japan was on top of the world and Europe anticipated great things, that the real economic growth of the United States during the next fifteen years would substantially exceed that of Japan and the EU? Awareness of that did not come until the late
title: deflation, difficulties at financial institutions, and anemic economic growth. In mid-2005, the Nikkei average hovered around 11,000, less than 30% of the 1989 peak. Over the same period, the American Dow Jones average, despite experiencing a late 1990s bubble that deflated in 2000–2002, advanced to 10,500, up nearly fourfold from its 1989 close
Japan and Europe became the large economies with problems, while the United States was comparatively prosperous

container-title: that of 1981–1982, when interest rates were at their peaks in U.S. history and the Federal Reserve was focused on ending the Great Inflation of 1966–1981. In 1982
note: the U.S. economy shrank by 1.9% compared with 1981. That was the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Compared to it, the 1990–1991 and 2001 recessions were mild indeed.
title: From the mid-1980s to 1995, the three advanced economic areas had similar growth rates. But from 1995 levels, the U.S. economy expanded in real terms by 45% through 2004, whereas the euro currency area grew only 19% and Japan 15%. The U.K. and Canada did better, growing 32% and 35%. Within the euro area there were some large differences. Germany grew only 13% from its 1995 level through 2004, while Ireland’s booming economy doubled in size. A remarkable feature of the recent U.S. economic expansion was its steadiness. In all but two of the years from 1990 through 2004, annual U.S. real growth rates ranged from 1.9% to 4.5%. The two exceptions were related to brief recessions. The 1990–1991 recession shrank the U.S. economy by 0.2% in 1991 as compared with

The 2001 recession did not shrink it at all year over year, but merely reduced the 2001 growth rate to 0.8%. The mildness of these last two recessions might be contrasted with the one that came before them
The steadiness of U.S. economic growth since 1990, even since the recession of 1981–1982, was by no means matched by the behavior of

note: Clearly, this is an approximation that is only roughly correct for low rates of inflation.
title: An exact formula for the one-year real rate is (1 + i)/(1 + p) − 1, where i is the nominal, or market, rate of interest per annum and p is the expected oneyear inflation rate. The formula is equivalent mathematically to a real rate of (i − p)/(1 + p). It is often stated that the real rate of interest is the nominal, or market, rate less the inflation rate
